meanings.def: towards a place or position that is in front
examples: She leaned forward and kissed him on the cheek.
He took two steps forwards.
They ran forward to welcome her.
The procession slowly moved forward.
Turn your wrists so that your palms face forward.
He stands by the fire, rocking backward and forward.

meanings.def: towards the future; ahead in time
examples: Looking forward, we hope to expand our operations in several of our overseas branches.
The next scene takes the story forwards five years.
The series moves back and forward through time.
(old use) from this day forward
We consider this agreement to be an important step forward.
Cutting our costs is the only way forward.
We are not getting any further forward with the discussion.
The project will go forward (= continue) as planned.
The 21st century has seen trade between the two countries leap forward.
It was decided to bring the meeting forward two weeks.

meanings.def: in or towards the front part of a ship or plane
examples: forward of something The main cabin is situated forward of (= in front of) the mast.

meanings.def: from one place or position to another and back again many times
examples: She rocked backwards and forwards on her chair.
The film skips backwards and forwards through time.

meanings.def: in the future, starting from now
examples: We have a very solid financial position going forward.
The strategy going forward is still undecided.
Moving forward, we need to have a real plan.

meanings.def: to make a great effort to do something, especially if it is difficult or you are feeling tired
to change the time shown by clocks, usually by one hour, when the time changes officially, for example at the beginning and end of summer
examples: Remember to put your clocks back tonight.

idioms.def: from one place or position to another and back again many times
examples: She rocked backwards and forwards on her chair.
The film skips backwards and forwards through time.

idioms.def: in the future, starting from now
examples: We have a very solid financial position going forward.
The strategy going forward is still undecided.
Moving forward, we need to have a real plan.

idioms.def: to make a great effort to do something, especially if it is difficult or you are feeling tired
to change the time shown by clocks, usually by one hour, when the time changes officially, for example at the beginning and end of summer
examples: Remember to put your clocks back tonight.

meanings.def: directed or moving towards the front
examples: The door opened, blocking his forward movement.
a forward pass (= in a sports game)

meanings.def: located in front, especially on a ship, plane or other vehicle
examples: the forward cabins
A bolt may have fallen off the plane's forward door.
the forward movement of history
A little forward planning at the outset can save you a lot of expense.
The plans are still no further forward than they were last month.

meanings.def: behaving towards somebody in a manner that is too confident or too informal
examples: I hope you don't think I'm being too forward.

meanings.def: to send or pass goods or information to somebody
examples: forward something to somebody We will be forwarding our new catalogue to you next week.
forward somebody something We will be forwarding you our new catalogue next week.
I’m forwarding you this email that I had from Jeff.
forward something to forward a request/complaint/proposal

meanings.def: to send a letter, etc. received at the address a person used to live at to their new address
examples: forward something (to somebody) Could you forward any mail to us in New York?
forward (something) I put ‘please forward’ on the envelope.

meanings.def: to help to improve or develop something
examples: He saw the assignment as a way to forward his career.
She uses various devices to forward the plot.
They have done a great deal to forward the cause of world peace.

meanings.def: an attacking player whose position is near the front of a team in some sports
